151425707.review:
Como apasionado jugador tanto de juegos indies como de otros tipos, me sumergí en Hotline Miami con expectativas moderadas y salí de él completamente cautivado. Este juego, que inicialmente parece una amalgama de estética retro y violencia pixelada, se revela como una obra maestra adictiva que fusiona brillantemente el diseño de niveles desafiantes con una estética única.

Desde el primer momento, quedé atrapado en la atmósfera envolvente de los años 80, donde la música synthwave y los neones saturados crean un telón de fondo perfecto para la acción frenética. La banda sonora,no solo es un acompañamiento, sino un componente esencial que impulsa la experiencia a otro nivel. La música y la acción están sincronizadas de manera tan magistral que cada movimiento se convierte en una coreografía letal, elevando la adrenalina a niveles insospechados.

Cada nivel es un rompecabezas táctico donde la planificación y la ejecución rápida son esenciales. La muerte se vuelve inevitable, pero cada reinicio es una oportunidad para perfeccionar tu estrategia. La satisfacción de superar un nivel, después de innumerables intentos, es incomparable y alimenta la adicción al juego.

Lo que realmente me conquistó fue la narrativa intrigante y surrealista. Los giros inesperados y las interacciones con personajes enigmáticos mantuvieron mi interés en constante aumento. La historia se desenvuelve de manera no convencional, manteniendo un aire de misterio que te incita a seguir adelante para descubrir qué diablos está sucediendo (me recordo a cierto punto el protagonista en Ryan Gosling).

Sin duda alguna se lo recomiendo a cualquier persona que quiera pasar unas horas sufriendo y intentando superar los niveles con sus propias estrategias y que se cautive de la misma manera que yo lo he hecho. 

Att: Link

150467661.review:
The beginning of a savage duology, Hotline Miami takes a visceral landscape of the 1980s into a hyperviolent killing spree that feels inspired by the old Gauntlet games.  As a hitman-for-hire, you clear out entire buildings of trigger-happy thugs who are just as vulnerable as you, ready to die in a single hit from a bat or a bullet.

Some may find this rather overwhelming despite its simplistic furore, whilst others who enjoy the more repeat-and-kill type of games can get lost easily in the haze.  The art style is beautifully hideous, with the few faces you meet being unsavoury against a neon hell, and the music takes a strong pastiche of 80s electronic wave through the lens of 2000s tech.  All in all, this is a fun game if you don't get easily frustrated by repeating the same segments again and again, as a game that encourages patience and a cool head to know the layout of a floor and who to kill first.  But the sequel is far better, and the original is not really required to enjoy it.

150332524.review:
I waited to drop a review on this game until I completed both this and the sequel as recommended by a friend.

-PROS-

• Great soundtrack
• Good retro graphics
• Masks add a variety of game play for different approaches to levels and play styles
• Confusing story but stays intriguing
• Progressively challenging game play

-CONS-

• Progressively challenging but also rage inducing, which can be negative for some people
• Doors are buggy. REALLY buggy. Gunfire getting obstructed, melee attacks not working in the door frames, etc.
• Enemy A.I. is buggy, can get caught on walls and trip out
• If you don't plan on playing the sequel, it may require you to look up what exactly is going on in the story. It isn't explained well
• Melee 1v1's are sometimes RNG on you winning the fight
• Expect to get killed from off-screen enemies that you don't know are there until you play the maps multiple times via trial and error to map out the spawns
• Little replayability

-CONCLUSION-

7/10

Relatively short game that is fun when it works how it's intended. I had a good time with it. The $10 price point I think is fair and it's even better if you can pick it up on sale.

149344439.review:
Hotline Miami stands as a remarkable testament to the ingenuity and creativity of the indie gaming industry. Its excellence lies in several key areas that make it a standout title for gamers of various backgrounds and interests.

First and foremost, the gameplay in Hotline Miami is impeccably designed. The controls are finely tuned, allowing for precise movements and actions. This level of control is crucial, especially in a game where split-second decisions can determine success or failure. The game's tight mechanics cater to a wide range of players, from those seeking a challenging experience to those looking for a more casual gaming session.

The level design is another highlight of Hotline Miami. Each stage is crafted with meticulous attention to detail, presenting a diverse array of challenges and opportunities for strategic thinking. The arrangement of enemies, obstacles, and weapons demands thoughtful planning and execution. This aspect of the game appeals to players who relish in problem-solving and adapting to unforeseen circumstances.

Hotline Miami's narrative style is both cryptic and surreal, leaving much open to interpretation. This approach creates a sense of mystery and invites players to piece together the narrative from fragmented clues. It offers a unique storytelling experience, blending historical elements with a touch of the surreal. This narrative style is likely to engage players with an interest in unraveling complex and enigmatic stories.

The game's retro aesthetic and pulsating soundtrack pay homage to the history of video games. The pixel art style evokes a sense of nostalgia, reminiscent of early gaming experiences. The soundtrack, filled with synthwave and electronic beats, complements the frenetic gameplay, immersing players in the neon-soaked world of Hotline Miami. This fusion of visuals and audio creates a distinctive atmosphere that sets the game apart.

Finally, Hotline Miami's success in the indie gaming industry is a testament to the potential for financial success in the gaming world. The game garnered critical acclaim and a dedicated fan base, demonstrating that even smaller, independent studios have the potential to create blockbuster titles. This success story serves as an inspiration for aspiring game developers and showcases the vibrant and competitive landscape of the indie gaming scene.

In conclusion, Hotline Miami's exceptional gameplay, intricate level design, unique narrative style, and homage to gaming history make it a standout title in the gaming world. Its technical prowess, combined with its success as an indie game, demonstrates the potential for financial prosperity in the industry. Whether a player is drawn to the challenge of precise execution, the thrill of strategic planning, or the allure of enigmatic storytelling, Hotline Miami offers an unforgettable gaming experience.

149318809.review:
A pumping, electronic soundtrack amplifies your mental state and the psychedelic colors as the player rushes through the doors and attempts to kill every single soul on that floor of the building. Bright flashes, pumping music, blood and a mechanic urge to kill faster, more efficiently and without mistake. The music amplifies this hypnotizing essence that allows you to blend and merge with your harsh reality, listening to it makes you feel at ease when killing and like you're just letting the adrenaline rush take you through the murder spree
 
the game deliberately urges the player forward through its music and visuals but then lurches them back through uncertainty in the narrative and the sheer horror of the violence on screen.
the music that has been guiding the rush dies to leave an eerie soundscape as you backtrack past the many fallen foes, the carnage you’ve left behind. It’s an uneasy sight.
 
The trick that Hotline Miami employs perfectly is offering no time for thought during its violent gameplay and then offering abundant need for reflection through pause and uncertainty of narrative achieved by unique combination of interactivity, visuals, audio, dialogue and atmosphere that only games can offer. 

Jacket is pretty relatable. Having a messy or unorganized home, relying on instant gratification (like junk food, watching movies, smoking cigarettes and visiting bars) to cope with stress and relax, being mentally at the brink of collapse, finding it difficult to let things go, having a horrible time dealing with grief and letting his emotions control him, rage get the best of him. He may never utter a single word, but the music choices that have a surrealistic haze, mirrors the incredibly distorted line between reality and dream he finds himself in and expresses his feelings for him.
 
You start to wonder whether the protagonist sanity allows his perspective to be even trustworthy, you no longer know what’s real, you are no longer certain of how justified the violence is, and that's exactly the neutral perspectives Hotline Miami fully embodies in its application of violence: it does not glorify it, nor vilify it. It is what it is.

149116063.review:
Fast and visceral, as much as top-down view and pixelated graphics allow. Both the player character and the enemies are quick to go down, there seems to be no penalty for dying, and restarting happens at the press of a key. The contrasting colours make environments mostly easy to read, at least until the carnage accompanied by electronic music begins.

More often than not, the controls are very responsive, though sometimes it feels like picking up a weapon does not always register. In addition, it is also unclear how the game logic determines which weapon to pick up from a pile. A melee weapon might get picked up over a firearm, and there is no way to choose if they are too close to each other. Since stopping to go through them all might ruin a combo chain, adapting to what one gets seems to be the way to go. It certainly helps to get acquainted with the arsenal which spawns randomly in the levels, as, for instance, some weapons only allow a single-use ranged attack, and firearms do not seem to damage enemies standing too close to the player character.

Enemies are pretty sensitive and practically have eyes in the back of their heads. There is no stealth to speak of beyond using a silent weapon to take out a lone enemy. There are some inconsistencies in enemy behaviour and reaction time, but they are generally predictable. Do keep an eye out for enemies who are only knocked down, as they will get back up and rearm if not finished off in time. They might be tricky to spot at first because enemies frequently pile on top of each other as they rush the player.

The rating system features some peculiarities - some seemingly quick and relatively clean runs may be awarded fewer points than other, slower, more gory ones. The game, it appears, awards more points to a run in which the player is always on the move, gets frequently spotted, knocks enemies down with swinging doors, and favours fists over weapons. At the same time, amusingly, the game's loading screen tips warn against doing anything rash as well as encourage recklessness. The mask of the frog - "Zack" - extends combo windows, having thus boosted my scores just enough to get A+ ratings on all levels, but it was a bit of a grind.

Some achievements did not unlock when they should have done, but they all worked eventually. Perhaps somewhat irritatingly, this could mean the achievement for acquiring all masks may unlock before an achievement for acquiring a particular one. Just in case, upon picking up a puzzle piece or performing an action required for an achievement, finish the current chapter.

This is one of those brilliant success stories where a small team with little resources hits the market with something so different and unique that it shakes the very foundations of the video game world. Or at least for a while.

I remember when [i]Hotline Miami[/i] came out in 2012, it looked like [i]GTA 1[/i] or [i]2[/i] to me, and based on that, I decided to give it a try without really looking into it. Needless to say, trying to play [i]Hotline Miami[/i] like the first [i]GTA[/i]s won't get you too far :P

Now, in 2023, after delving properly into it, it became clear what the fuss was all about and why this game became so popular. It requires insane reflexes and speed and is just so punishing, where only 1 millisecond and/or 1 millimeter determines either your success or failure, creating an unprecedented atmosphere. And in that light, trying to get an A+ for all the chapters is so addictive and fun that it becomes a phenomenon in itself. Add to that a great soundtrack, a nice retro vibe, and a mysterious-cryptic story, and you'll get the record-breaking [i]Hotline Miami[/i] that crazes so many gamers to this day.

Una joyita que había jugado brevemente hace tiempo pero nunca me había pasado a pesar de ser un tremendo juegazo. El frenetismo de Doom se suma a la dificultad de Ghostrunner con estética vaporwave psicodélica de vista cenital.

En Hotline Miami somos un sicario que recibe misiones de despejar edificios de enemigos mediante llamadas   de teléfono crípticas sin saber muy bien desde donde y por qué. La historia es lo menos importante y es muy astracta resolviéndose en parte hacia el final del juego y sirviendo solo como escusa para un maravilloso gameplay. 

El juego básicamente consiste en la sucesión de misiones en las que debemos de eliminar a todos los enemigos de la sala usando las herramientas disponibles y diferentes máscaras que confieren diferentes habilidades, todo esto desde un punto de vista isométrico pixelado y con música electrónica de fondo. Lo mas notorio de esto es que de un solo golpe o disparo moriremos, así como la gran mayoría de enemigos, podría sonar aburrido pero como la reaparición es instantánea y el juego se guarda entre piso y piso se incita mucho el reintento hasta conseguir pasar superarlo nivel, además de que la dificultad tampoco es excesiva y todos los niveles acaban por superarse.

Si te gusta la violencia gratuita, los retos y la música machacona, Hotline Miami es tu juego.

I don't know how I never left a review for this game. Seriously, even to this day this game holds up just as well as the day it was released. The presentation is just the right mixture of gritty and absurd, it never feels too real while also not feeling like a parody. I honestly can't put into words exactly what makes this game so appealing, it's one of those strange titles that just has some secret sauce that fills the gaps and creates an overall fantastic experience. I also like that the game doesn't waste any time, and it feels like it's got just the right amount of exposition without ever going overboard. For me, I feel like a game does a great job if I finish it and I am left wanting just a little bit more, which this game certainly accomplished.

I don't know who hasn't played this game already, but if you haven't, check it out. It's short and worth your time.

148534075.review: Hotline Miami' is a pulsating adrenaline rush of neon, synth, and relentless action! Its retro aesthetic perfectly complements the frenzied pace, creating a unique atmosphere that's both nostalgic and refreshingly innovative. The soundtrack is an auditory masterpiece, driving each level's intensity to dizzying heights. But it's not just about the chaos; the strategic depth required to navigate through each stage adds layers of complexity. With its compelling narrative and challenging gameplay, 'Hotline Miami' isn't just a game — it's a vivid fever dream that leaves an indelible mark on your psyche. A flawless gem that redefines the indie gaming scene. 10/10 - a heart-pounding triumph

148521207.review: The game was fine, until it hit me with the "the enemies are predictable !"loading screen tip. So thats when I knew it wasn't on purpose, which is unfortunate. The game doesn't really work, enemies sometimes just know you are there, sometimes they don't, aiming is wonky, enemies can aggro and one tap you from off screen. You can hold shift but you can only look one way at a time. its hard to tell what is cover and what enemies can just see over, especially considering inconsistencies from run to run. The game is TRYING to be fast paced, but it isn't fair, so it forces the player to play slowly in order to beat levels.

148518999.review: It's 2023 and I played Hotline Miami for the first time. I would like to say that I almost never leave reviews so take that into account if you want. This was a game I've heard mentioned by friends and in videos, but I knew nothing about this game except for what the main character looked like. I didn't know what to expect out of this game. The music is beyond fantastic and the story is great with just the right amount of wtf is going on. The characters are memorable and the game play is fun. One of the things I appreciate if the difficulty of the game and how it's actually fair. When you die you rarely blame the game and you go back and try again. I could probably go on for a while but no matter what I say I don't think it'll do the game justice so if you never played Hotline Miami and you want to try it do it you'll not be disappointed. Thanks for reading.

148474845.review:
This is one of those games where they took a very simple concept and managed to make a hit game around it. It's one of those weird top down shooters that you probably played on flash game websites if you are a millennial, but there's a lot more going on here to make the concept work.

The combination of adrenaline fueled action gameplay, great music, immense violence, surreal imagery, and a ridiculously bleak setting makes for a strangely addictive experience. It's also fairly difficult on account of the fact that everything is a one shot kill.  The only problem is it's a very short game. It's very exciting experience that's over way too quickly. Luckily there's a sequel.

148225648.review:
Brutal, slick, and mysterious. 

The twists on certain missions add nice flavor but there are enough normal missions that it doesn't feel like the game is showing its hand gameplay wise until it decides it really needs to. Has the pace to work you into routine enough that you feel it meaningfully when things start falling apart. The game is just as long as it needs to be, feels appropriate to the pace this game wields. That pace being quick and ruthless.

Has a nice amount of challenge to it and has style in spades. If you can take the violent nature of this game, I firmly recommend it.

148225512.review:
I've never had so much fun and been so on edge at the same time. 

The fast pace of the levels while enjoying some good tunes is extremely exhilarating and gets my heart racing. The bright colours mixed with the chaos you ensue by the end of each mission are somehow the best match visually. Not to mention the humorous characters/dialogue along the way.

Some of the levels are difficult, but the play style makes me want to try again and again until I complete it, no matter how long it takes. 

Definitely recommend this game to anyone that wants to have some fun and doesn't mind mind some chaos.

147938870.review:
Hotline Miami is a full on adrenaline rush. Independent developers Jonatan Söderstrom and Dennis Wedin pushed GameMaker’s engine to bring players a singleplayer top-down action shooter bursting with character. The 2012 release is packed with incredibly fast-paced, brutal combat that’s masterfully accompanied by an exuberating soundtrack, perfectly encapsulating everything that the game has to offer and warranting a full-on collectors edition vinyl release in 2016.

The raw, pixelated and hyper combat-driven gameplay is highly challenging and often repetitively frustrating. This is driven by enemies that exhibit inhumane reactions, unpredictable behaviours and laser-like precision when it comes to gun-play. A single bullet or a deadly punch from these aggressive and emotionless foes can end a player’s run within seconds of being spotted. Adding to the difficulty, they are unfavourably hidden around the map, hardly noticeable or completely invisible to the player until it is far too late.

It is most certain that you will die over and over again. Frustratingly repeating the same level continuously. However, as this cycle continues, you will be getting slightly better each run. Mapping out the level layout, encoding enemy locations in your memory and reacting quicker and faster to any stimuli that Hotline Miami throws at you. Close encounters with enemies and a scenario where the player is constantly sitting on edge, coupled with an energetically repetitive synthwave soundtrack, the game masterfully sends the player into a captivating transfixed state of flow, making it almost impossible to pull away from. Fully neuron-activated, a player continues to mindlessly kill until successful, and when everything finally comes together, Hotline Miami is at it’s absolute best.

Overall, Hotline Miami is a gem and it can be recommended for those seeking a challenge. At times, clunky and unfair, the title that’s full of character is well addictive and satisfying for those willing to persevere, captivating gamers fully by utilising a state of flow that is hard to drop once hooked.

147764724.review:
Hotline Miami is a top-down shooter by Dennaton Games, where the player controls a mystery man of few words known only as Jacket as anonymous phone calls send him to perform hits on different places belonging to some sort of mafia.

Graphically the game is... Well it's primarily gorey pixel art from a top-down perspective with the added layer of trippy flashing colors, blinking lights, shakey camera, moving text... yeah, in general, the game gives a rather strong impression in that regard, and definitely isn't intended for those with epilepsy.

Sound design, you mostly get basic sound effects like gunshots, melee hits etc. The interesting part is the music, which is a hit-or-miss for me. Some of the electronic renditions are headbang-worthy (my favorites are Perturbator, Inner Animal, Knock and Turf Main), but some others just make me wish it would stop. Generally the more, well, trippy scenes have the less bearable music, which kinda fits I guess.

The gameplay is pretty much what you'd expect: get in and make sure everything dies. Every kill is bloody and, well, satisfying, if you have a tendency for being a psychopath. The game in general is a lot more technical than you'd think - while your enemies aren't very bright and will charge or shoot you the moment they see you and generally die to a single weapon hit or shot, the same applies to you, meaning cover and careful movement are your friends. There is a pretty large selection of weapons, melee and ranged alike, with each one behaving a little differently. You can charge in guns blazing and survive, but only if you're good enough to do it. The game also heavily encourages it with its combo system for kills, but that's only if you care about getting high scores (and unlocking some extra stuff). If you die, you can restart the entire floor instantly by pressing a single button, and you also get infinite lives, so it's fair in that regard. The game itself tends to be rather well balanced and not amazingly difficult, but fairly challenging at times, except for a few specific floors that can be a bit of a difficulty spike.

The story does not appear to be very clear at the start, with maybe some extra newspaper scraps you can find around the main character's house each day giving some background as to what the hit was about clearly. The normal ending also does not explain much either.However if you find all the puzzle pieces scattered across the levels and make a password out of it, you can see the true ending where you find out what is the actual purpose behind the mysterious phone calls.

Overall, this is a pretty good, if a little bit... sensory-overloading experience. The gameplay is fun but gets a little bit repetitive if you play for longer than an hour at a time, and the conclusion is actually a little deeper than you'd think. This definitely isn't a game for those who are sensitive to flashing lights or pixelated gore, but otherwise it's worth giving a try.

im writing this while being stuck at the "last chapter" and I am deleting this "aminakodumun" game its not a fast paced hack n slash, its rather a fastly random situational probability game.

The game has great aesthetic & music, but the game is clunky & largely unfair. Like you will have a dialogue window pop up & an enemy will attack you like .2 seconds after it closes, or you will have situations where you just can't damage the enemy for no good reason (for instance the cats in the aforementioned fight).

Like let me break it down to the issues I remember:
* You have to hold SHIFT 24/7 or else you can't see where the enemies are or aim effectively.
* No aiming settings.
* No option to turn off sway / shake.
* You die in one hit but enemies sometimes take multiple hits.
* Very little time given for reactions.
* Enemies will sometimes know exactly where you are even with their back turned.
* Enemies instantly aim at you & never really miss.
* Sometimes enemies don't get hit.
* Sometimes enemies hit you from farther than they should.
* Doors block everything & often waste your ammo.
* Enemies sometimes blend in with the background.
* The game hides the ammo meter after a mission making it hard to tell if you picked up a piece of garbage or a loaded weapon, this is an issue on some missions where they throw more enemies at you after a clear.
* You can't throw weapons at the first boss, but then suddenly this rule changes for a later boss where you have to throw a weapon.
* A boss throws a ton of dialogue at you & immediately attacks after the dialogue ends.
* Multiple phase bosses / fights (such as when police show up) not being checkpointed; so if you mess up it takes a long time to get back.

147629344.review:
If I was rating the game on a gore factor, Hotline Miami would be a 10/10. It’s a wonderfully fast-paced slasher game that takes place in an alternate universe where Russia won the Cold War. You play a mask-donning vigilante who takes orders from a mysterious caller that loves dialing *67. The orders? Kill every Russian at the target location, and ask no questions.
Yeah, you’re definitely not playing a good guy in this game. But if you’re willing to toss morals away for relentless surges of dopamine while you torpedo through levels and bop along to one of the greatest OSTs of all-time, then Hotline Miami is the game for you. Plan for a few jump scares from coked-up gang members zooming at you with a baseball bat. Oh, and lots of blood.

147111986.review:
Hotline Miami es un juego que se destaca por su valentía y originalidad. Desde el momento en que comienzas a jugar, te sumerges en un mundo de caos y decadencia que te atrapa por completo. La elección de colores vibrantes y la música electrónica frenética crean una atmósfera única que te sumerge en la experiencia de manera inmediata.

La jugabilidad es el punto fuerte de Hotline Miami. La acción es rápida, intensa y altamente adictiva. Cada nivel se convierte en un rompecabezas mortal en el que debes planificar tus movimientos cuidadosamente y ejecutarlos con precisión. La variedad de armas y máscaras te permite abordar los desafíos de diferentes maneras, lo que agrega profundidad a la jugabilidad.

La narrativa es intrigante y misteriosa. A medida que avanzas en la historia, te enfrentas a decisiones morales impactantes que te hacen cuestionar tus acciones y el significado de la violencia en el juego. Esta narrativa evocadora se combina perfectamente con el estilo visual y la música para crear una experiencia inmersiva.

Además, la dificultad del juego es un desafío bien equilibrado. Cada muerte te enseña algo nuevo y te motiva a intentarlo una vez más. La sensación de logro al superar un nivel difícil es gratificante y mantiene a los jugadores comprometidos.

146646679.review:
Hotline Miami is a magnum opus of combat with extreme violence, the unique of its kind where it pits you in a one against all situation every step of the way, giving you ample tools around each passing area you come across, ranging from melee to outright fire arms at your disposal. The achievements, should you dedicate your time to completing them along your countless playthrough of infinite replay value, should be easy to get once you figure the ins and outs of what you are supposed to do, and with extreme prejudice.

The story begins in the late 80s, as you are in the shoes of the chicken mask person, Jacket, who answers various phone calls from an unknown source, that are giving you various tasks to do in certain locations. However, the various tasks you do are not as they seem. During the story, you are up against dozens of white suits who are all out for you and will take every inch to stop you with a smash or a gun blast. And your goal may be to eradicate all of them, but on the other side, you're killing the enemy suits as violently as possible. And the setting where the calls instruct you to go is always indoors.

In the game mechanics side of things, you will always be rewarded weaponry for furthering your score on each level you play, but the masks that you find throughout the levels provide different perks that you can experiment with. One can give you accuracy, grant you fist kills, or even make you go faster than your normal speed. Combos that you accrue from consecutive kills will reward you perfectly, and it will be counted for in the post-level statistics that will give you a rank based on your play style and what tactics and tricks you have used.

The music is top notch stuff from various artists, e.g. El Huervo (who had gone on to make art work for the sequel), M|O|O|N, Scattle, and Perturbator. The electronic synthwave styles invoke the right feeling that Hotline Miami has gone for, as well as the songs being the favorites of many HLM fans who could have them on repeat, or a fancy little playlist they can listen to on a few moments of chill time. Even I appreciate the soundtrack at its core, because the artists have made an excellent work capturing the feel of the game in their entirety. In case I'd want to share my toast of gameplay and I'd want to minimize copyright, I'd replace that marked material with stuff along the lines of artists like Immorpher and Aleks with a K, but have a remix of Miami by Razer, making the statistics sound like it's supposed to.

All in all, I'm daring to recommend Hotline Miami to anyone who is seeking violent adrenaline combat that is majorly expected from this top down arcade shooter. It will give you a test of a fighting time-bomb against all odds, but it'll cause a pain of trial and error on a few instances if you are not careful enough. Experiment with different tactics, play out your combos, and you will be well rewarded.

Hotline Miami is one of the most rage inducing games out there. You will lose your temper from the extremely small time window you have to kill Russian mobsters to rack up points, and you will die so many times it gets very annoying quickly!!! Most of the deaths will be for very stupid reasons and have you questioning why those bullets went through that one guy and didn't do a thing to him. The fucking aiming sucks with lots of input lag, the graphics aren't that great from a top down view, the characters look very ugly too and the story doesn't make much sense. You just resort to cheesing enemies to you by getting them to walk over to you near a door or a corner of a wall so you can take them out with melee.

This game is just fucking garbage, and you need a lot of patience and determination to fucking get through it all without breaking your entire gaming setup over it. I don't understand why this game has an overwhelmingly positive review score, Its just overrated! 

Don't buy this game at all!

145383130.review:
[b]"Hotline Miami" is a top down shooter with unique, cult vibes, a mysterious dark story, enigmatic characters, amazing music and enjoyable fast paced battles that require some thinking and good planning. Yet, it can get extremely frustrating due to its clunky, imprecise mechanics and monotonous because of its gameplay that never evolves neither adds new elements gradually. It's a game for fans of the genre only or maybe for old arcade games loves.


Manometer: 6/10[/b] 


The good
- Unique, genuine atmosphere that reminds me the movies cult wave of '90s. You smell the blood, feel the tension in the air and it's hard to tell apart reality from illusions.
- Good lore. Mysterious story with enigmatic characters, twists and some psychological thriller elements. 
- Despite the clunky mechanics and the precision issues, gameplay can be enjoyable from time to time. Battles have great pacing. They're fast, but sometimes you may need to stop and think of you next moves. You have to find the best route inside each level, who to execute first, how to use doors etc. Most missions can be completed in various ways.
- Amazing electronic music that enhances battles' rhythm and fits perfectly to the visual vibes.
- It has some moments of inspiring humor and well written dialogues.
- Tons of blood and brutal kills offer the ultimate splatter experience.
- A lot of masks and weapons to unlock gives the player some extra motivation to achieve higher scores.

The bad
- Clunky, imprecise mechanics. You're never sure that your bullets will hit the target even in a straight line. Thinks get worse when shooting behind doors and corners. Melee weapons' reach is inconsistent. Half of your frustrating deaths are caused due to its inconsistency.
- Gameplay never evolves. You don't acquire skills or abilities. You find some new weapons that don't make much of a difference. Each mission is essentially the same thing over and over again. Levels look similar, enemies are always the same generic guys. It can get monotonous after a while.
- Dump, inconsistent NPCs' AI. Enemies can see only in a straight line, they don't react to dead bodies, they forget of you easily, they don't hear a thing when you melee kill guys next to them, you can trick them easily. Sometimes the entire level hears your shotguns and others not even the guy in the same room as you. There is no logic at all.
- Questionable aesthetics. I know it's part of the cult concept, but this colorful collage of low quality, grainy textures looks messy. Battles' sounds are silly and annoying too.
- Music is great but plays almost all the time at the background and gets tiring. Some moments of silence would be great.

145211938.review:
Hotline Miami is really a very entertaining, addictive and challenging top-down shooter that I really enjoy.
It's not just a shooter where you can just shoot around, but you really have to put your brain to work.
The controls work nicely on both platforms and together with the brutal action and the beautiful sounding 80's soundtrack I had the greatest difficulty to stop playing.

The game also works great on a steam deck: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rGOkMgaKwN8

The controls and fast action cannot hide the fact that this is really just a puzzle game.
Enemies behave quite predictably, for example by walking the same circle all the time.
You have to think about how best to complete a room full of opponents. Do you throw a beer bottle at someone's head and then knock the other person down, at the risk of being hit yourself?
Or do you storm into the room with guns at the ready? And if you do fire shots, how do you deal with the mob of guards approaching the noise?
Hotline Miami is the most focused, no nonsense game I've played in years.
Even the graphics are perfect in that regard: the pixels are detailed enough to show what's happening, but also abstract enough to let you experience the nasty story in your head.
In combination with the LSD-like bad trip that the psychedelic electro lets you experience, Hotline Miami is an uncomfortable yet impressive and unforgettable experience.

145147709.review:
"Hotline Miami es una joya en el mundo de los videojuegos independientes que cautiva con su estilo visual único y su apasionante jugabilidad. Desde el momento en que te sumerges en su atractiva estética retro y te sumerges en su vibrante atmósfera de los años 80, te das cuenta de que estás a punto de experimentar algo realmente especial.

La combinación de acción frenética y sigilo estratégica es una obra maestra en sí misma. Cada nivel se convierte en un emocionante rompecabezas en el que debes trazar tu camino a través de una serie de enemigos y obstáculos. La rapidez y la precisión son esenciales, y cada muerte y resurrección se convierten en un paso hacia la mejora y el dominio de cada escenario.

Pero más allá de su jugabilidad adictiva, Hotline Miami logra contar una historia intrigante y enigmática que te mantiene enganchado de principio a fin. Los misteriosos mensajes en el contestador telefónico y los personajes ambiguos añaden una capa de profundidad a la narrativa, haciendo que cada nivel se sienta como un rompecabezas en un rompecabezas más grande.

La banda sonora electrónica es una pieza fundamental en la experiencia. Las pulsantes canciones se sincronizan perfectamente con la acción en pantalla, elevando la intensidad de cada momento y sumergiéndote aún más en el mundo del juego.

Hotline Miami es un recordatorio de que los gráficos en píxeles pueden ser increíblemente poderosos cuando se combinan con un diseño de nivel ingenioso y una jugabilidad que te hace sentir en control de cada movimiento arriesgado que haces. Es un juego que te desafía a superar tus propios límites, pero al mismo tiempo te recompensa con una satisfacción inigualable cuando finalmente triunfas.

En resumen, Hotline Miami es una experiencia única y emocionante que fusiona la nostalgia con la innovación. Si estás buscando un juego que te haga pensar, te mantengas en vilo y te sumerja en una atmósfera inolvidable, no busques más. Este juego es un testimonio del poder creativo de los desarrolladores independientes y una adición imprescindible a la colección de cualquier amante de los videojuegos.

144928275.review:
[h1] If you don't want to rage, just get JYDGE instead. [/h1]
Hotline Miami has great aesthetic & music (highly recommend buying the soundtrack), but the game is clunky, unfair, & lacks accessibility options.

Like you will have a dialogue window pop up & an enemy will attack you like ~0.2 seconds after it closes, or you will have situations where you just can't damage the enemy because of invincibility frames or wonky hitboxes. Also I seriously cannot tell if my game is bugged or if the game is supposed to be this fast.

Like let me break it down to the issues I remember:
* You have to hold SHIFT 24/7 or else you can't see where the enemies are or aim effectively.
* No aiming settings.
* No option to turn off sway / shake.
* You die in one hit but enemies sometimes take multiple hits.
* Very little time given for reactions.
* Enemies will sometimes know exactly where you are even with their back turned.
* Enemies instantly aim at you & never really miss.
* Sometimes enemies don't take damage.
* Sometimes enemies hit you from farther than they should.
* Doors block everything & be a nuisance often wasting your ammo.
* Enemies sometimes blend in with the background.
* The game hides the ammo meter after a mission making it hard to tell if you picked up a piece of garbage or a loaded weapon, this is an issue on some missions where they throw more enemies at you after a clear.
* You can't throw weapons at the first boss, but then this rule changes for a later boss where you have to throw a weapon.
* A boss throws a wall of dialogue at you & attacks immediately after the dialogue ends giving little time to react.
* Multiple phase bosses / fights (such as when police show up) not being checkpointed; so if you mess up it can be tedious.
* Arbitrary limits (can't go to certain spots in boss fights or you will be instant killed, certain moves are only working in certain fights / phases, boss fights don't let you bring in weapons).
* Terrible hitboxes / damage registration.

I would recommend the following over Hotline Miami:
Jydge: 3D, 2 player, customizable.
Synthetik 1: 2D, Try Synthetik Arena to see if you'd like it.
Synthetik 2: 3D, (In development will have local co op at a later date).

144831727.review:
"Hotline Miami" is like a fever dream of neon-soaked violence, and it's so good that you'll question your own sanity while playing it. This game is the unhinged lovechild of a '80s action movie, a retro arcade, and a heavy dose of mind-bending drugs.

From the moment I booted up "Hotline Miami," I was transported to a surreal and pulsating world that's equal parts hilarious and disturbing. The game's top-down view and pixelated graphics give it a nostalgic charm, but don't let that fool you; this is a rollercoaster ride through the darkest recesses of the human psyche.

The core gameplay is an adrenaline-fueled ballet of death. You play as a nameless hitman receiving cryptic messages on your answering machine, instructing you to visit various locations and eliminate everyone inside. Armed with an array of weapons, from baseball bats to shotguns, you'll leave a trail of carnage in your wake.

The speed and precision required to succeed in "Hotline Miami" is both exhilarating and maddening. You'll die. A lot. But the game's quick respawn system ensures you're back in the action within seconds, fueling an addictive "just one more try" mentality.

One of the standout features is the game's soundtrack. The '80s-inspired synthwave beats are not only catchy but also perfectly complement the game's frenetic pace. The music becomes an integral part of the experience, driving you forward with a manic energy.

The story, delivered in a cryptic and surreal manner, is like a jigsaw puzzle of madness. As you progress through the game, you'll question your own motivations, the reliability of your character's perception, and the very nature of reality. It's a narrative that's both thought-provoking and absurd.

"Hotline Miami" doesn't take itself seriously, and that's part of its charm. The bizarre dialogue, surreal settings, and the game's willingness to throw you headfirst into the abyss of its narrative make it a dark comedy of sorts.

In conclusion, "Hotline Miami" is a game that's as funny as it is serious, as mind-bending as it is entertaining. It's a wild, drug-fueled trip through a neon-drenched hellscape, and you'll love every deranged minute of it. Just remember to keep a grip on your sanity as you dance with death to one of the catchiest soundtracks in gaming history.

144736475.review:
Hotline Miami es un buen juego de acción con gráficos retro en 2D con perspectiva de plano cenital en el que destrozaremos a un montón de rusos de la mafia en un Miami ochentero de una línea temporal alternativa.

La banda sonora es BESTIAL. Las melodías synthwave te hacen querer seguir jugando, al ritmo que masacras a oleadas de personas. La jugabilidad es sencilla aunque un poco tosca de aprender y dominar. Se puede volver difícil si te cuesta apuntar, sobre todo con los movimientos de la cámara psicodélica.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3023400436
El argumento del juego es un poco fumada, pero está bien. Intentan inculcarte culpa por "matar sin sentido" debido al pasado de Jacket, el protagonista de esta entrega,[spoiler]que sufre de estrés postraumático tras la guerra[/spoiler]aunque sinceramente, cuesta empatizar con un tío que no dice ni mu y que tiene las pintas de un pollo del Minecraft.
Hay muchas cosas por descubrir y cabos sueltos que se atan en la secuela y en el episodio del epílogo. 

En general es un muy buen juego, pero no creo que sea para todo el mundo.
No te lo compres si eres una persona que se marea con facilidad. Típicamente puedo aguantar lo que sea, pero en Hotline Miami hay algunas escenas en las que hay mucho parpadeo de colores y movimientos de cámara abruptos. Solo ocurren en muy contadas ocasiones, pero pueden llegar a marearte, y si eres fotosensible te puede llegar a doler la cabeza en estos niveles.

Por lo demás es un jueguito con mucha rejugabilidad, una historia divertida y una banda sonora ochentera tecno pop que te hará apreciarlo un montón. Si te ha gustado este, debes jugar la secuela.

I have immense respect for Hotline Miami, it's sequel, and especially it's developers for kickstarting a massive era of Indie Games, but at the end of the day, it truly is a Skill Issue for me. 143966571.review:
La premisa del juego es simple pero efectiva: asume el papel de un asesino a sueldo anónimo que recibe misteriosas instrucciones a través de mensajes telefónicos en contestadoras. Armado con una variedad de armas y habilidades, tu objetivo es infiltrarte en edificios infestados de enemigos y aniquilarlos de manera rápida y brutal. La mecánica de juego se basa en el ensayo y error, lo que significa que cada nivel es un rompecabezas mortal que debe resolver a través de la experimentación y la agilidad mental.

Lo que hace que Hotline Miami sea tan fascinante es su combinación única de elementos. La jugabilidad rápida y frenética se fusiona perfectamente con la estética retro pixelada y la paleta de colores neón, creando una experiencia visual y auditiva sorprendentemente adictiva. La banda sonora, compuesta por artistas como Perturbator y MOON, contribuye significativamente a la atmósfera hipnótica del juego y aumenta la sensación de estar inmerso en un mundo distorsionado.

El juego también juega con la mente del jugador a través de su narrativa intrigante ya menudo confusa. A medida que avanzas, te enfrentas a preguntas sobre la naturaleza de tus acciones y la moralidad en un mundo violento y caótico. Los encuentros con personajes enigmáticos y los giros argumentales mantienen la historia cautivadora a lo largo de la experiencia.

En cuanto a la recomendación, Hotline Miami es una elección ideal para aquellos que buscan un desafío estimulante y una experiencia única. Su estilo retro, su jugabilidad intensa y su narrativa intrigante se combinan para ofrecer una experiencia de juego que se destaca entre la multitud. Sin embargo, es importante tener en cuenta que el juego contiene violencia gráfica y temas maduros, por lo que es más adecuado para jugadores adultos que pueden apreciar su enfoque artístico y su naturaleza provocada. Si estás dispuesto a sumergirte en un mundo de caos estilizado y misterio de los años 80, Hotline Miami definitivamente merece un lugar en tu lista de juegos para probar.

143222310.review: Hotline Miami es una montaña rusa de adrenalina y caos pixelado que me ha mantenido al borde de la silla desde el primer disparo. Después de intensas sesiones de juego y dedicación, finalmente he logrado desbloquear el codiciado logro de A+ en todos los capítulos. Este logro no solo es un símbolo de mi perseverancia, sino también de mi inevitable inmersión en la locura psicodélica y la música hipnotizante del juego. Cada nivel es un desafío intenso que requiere precisión, rapidez y una pizca de suerte. La satisfacción de ver el rango A+ parpadeando en la pantalla es indescriptible, aunque debo admitir que el proceso me ha llevado al borde de la propia locura que el juego retrata. Si estás dispuesto a abrazar la violencia estilizada y la locura desenfrenada, Hotline Miami es una experiencia que te mantendrá al borde de la cordura en cada paso del camino.

I just finished the main story and it quickly became one of my favorite videogames.

It takes only one attack to kill you, so you should be quick and strategic as you kill all the enemies to progress. The gameplay is unique and fun while also being challenging. Overall, Hotline Miami is a fast and violent game for people who want a challenge filled with destructive mayhem.

142476840.review:
[b]Descripción general[/b] Te llaman, realizas tu trabajo de "limpieza" y a seguir con tu vida. Pero puede que te cueste algo que no se paga con dinero... shooter de vista aérea y con muchas vísceras. Pero al protagonista eso parece no importarle.

[b]Puntos positivos del juego[/b]:
- El sistema de puertas es un gran punto a favor. Grandes heroínas si las usas a tu favor :D
- Pocos requisitos, que eso siempre es un punto a favor.
- No te hace perder mucho el tiempo con la historia. Simple y directa para que cumplas con los encargos de las misiones.

[b]Puntos negativos del juego[/b]:
- Si no estas acostumbrado a este tipo de shooters... te van a matar unas cuantas veces.
- Los cadáveres no respetan mucho el concepto "pared" :(
- Que al quitar el juego te salten los que componen la música CADA VEZ no es algo que mole cuando quieres terminar de jugar

[b]Valoración general[/b]:
Acción directa. Es una buena manera para quitarte el estrés de encima. Recomendado.
